title: 110_hr3159
content: The Act titled "Ensuring Military Readiness Through Stability and Predictability Deployment Policy Act of 2007" mandates minimum periods of rest and recuperation for units of the Armed Forces between deployments. The Act mandates minimum periods of rest between deployments for units of the Armed Forces specified in paragraph (3) in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom. Congress recommends that this rest period should be at least twice the duration of the most recent previous deployment. The Act mandates minimum rest periods between deployments for specified units of the Armed Forces in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom. Units must have a rest period at least three times longer than their most recent deployment before being deployed again. The Act mandates a minimum rest period of five years between deployments for specified units of the Armed Forces in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom, including Army Reserve, Army National Guard, and Marine Corps Reserve units. The Act mandates a minimum rest period of five years between deployments for specified units of the Armed Forces in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom, including Army Reserve, Army National Guard, Marine Corps Reserve, Navy Reserve, Air Force Reserve, and Air National Guard units. Exemptions include special operations forces and units needed for redeployment assistance. The President may waive the limitations. The President may waive the limitation on deployment of Armed Forces units for national security threats. Military Chiefs can waive limitations for voluntary mobilizations. In this Act, deployment refers to relocating forces and materiel to desired areas of operations, including activities from origin to destination. The Commandant of the Marine Corps and the Chief of Staff of the Air Force can waive limitations for voluntary mobilizations. The term "unit" in this Act refers to a deployable unit commanded by a commissioned officer of the Army, Navy, Air Force, or Marine Corps. This Act will take effect on the date of its enactment. The House of Representatives passed the Act on August 2, 2007. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk. By Deborah M. Spriggs, Deputy Clerk.
